Example 6. If  VC = 
 
 $V = V_0 \sin q$ and $C = \cos (q - \phi)$, find the average value of the power, i.e., the average value of VC.

blocks.description: The product of voltage and the cosine of the phase difference.

blocks.text: Also the period is given by $T = \frac{2\pi}{\omega}$.

Hence the m.v. of VC is: 
 
 $\text{m.v.} = \frac{1}{T} \int_0^T VC \, dt$

blocks.description: Expression for the mean value of the product.

blocks.text:
We can use the identity: 
 
 $\cos (A - B) = \cos A \cos B + \sin A \sin B$

blocks.description: Identity for cosine of a difference.

blocks.text:
Thus, we have: 
 
 $VC = V_0 \sin q \left( \cos q \cos \phi + \sin q \sin \phi \right)$.
 
 Therefore, we can write an integral to find the mean value.

blocks.description: Integral formulation for finding the mean value.

blocks.text: If we let $C = \frac{1}{2}\int \sin^2 q \, dq = \frac{1}{2} \left( q - \frac{1}{2} \sin(2q) \right) + C$.

blocks.description: Constant of integration for the mean value.
